I have added scans of the other side of the tsuba to the folder below.  I f=
orgot to mention the dimensions again, so for the record they are 90.1 mm H=
 x 84.1 mm W x 5.0 - 5.5 mm thick at the mimi.

The maker is Nobuie and the=
 signature is of the type now called futoji-mei =E5=A4=AA=E5=AD=97=E9=8A=98=
 (bold, thick).  Within both the hanare and futoji-mei types there is consi=
derable variation in the detail of the signatures.  This example is not one=
 of the more boldly executed futoji-mei.  As Pete crypictically indicated, =
an oshigata of this guard is published in Nakamura Kakudayu and Akiyama Kyu=
saku's 1926 Nobuie Tsuba shu (#52).  There the signature is described as su=
mari-mei =E8=A9=B0=E3=82=8A=E9=8A=98 ("close packed"), which is one of the =
older terms now included within the futoji-mei type.  This guard is describ=
ed as futoji-mei in several later books and in the NBTHK's attribution.

Th=
e hitsuana had not yet been filled when the oshigata was made.  This guard =
was the property of the Okubo daimyo family in Odawara until it was sold in=
 1931, so the ana were likely filled by the new owner.  It is unlikely that=
 they are original to the plate given that they are made such that the guar=
d would be mounted with the unsigned side as the front.  The shapes of the =
hitsuana are unusual.   It was clearly mounted with an o-kozuka, which are =
typically 18-20 mm wide (vs. the standard size of 14-15 mm).  As Gordon men=
tioned, the small size of the kogai-ana suggests it was mounted with one of=
 the narrow style ko-Mino kogai.  The opening is too small to accommodate a=
 standard 14-15 mm wide kogai.

The early Edo period "betsujin" (different =
person) Nobuie work will lack the quality in the metal, tekkotsu, finish an=
d carving.  The plates are usually rather characterless and the working lac=
ks subtlety.  The late Edo period revival pieces do indeed try to emulate t=
he finish of the originals and as Alan mentioned some do a fairly good job.=
  In general, the working of the rim is a bit forced and overdone in these =
examples compared to the originals.  They obviously will look young, but th=
ere is also a somewhat artificial quality to them.  The same feeling comes =
from later copies of early Shino and Oribe ceramics.

The metal, tekkotsu a=
nd yakite finish should lead to an Owari origin.  Remember that Kaneie work=
ed in Kyoto, and everything about his guards is in line with Kyoto methods =
and aesthetics.

That's all I can think of at the moment.
